rows.title: Body Scan

transcript.eng:
Today's pause is called a body scan. Begin by closing your eyes or maintaining a soft gaze. 
Take a full breath in and a long breath out.
Now, bringing awareness to the top of your body,
your head,
face,
neck,
shoulders.
Noticing any sensations, movements, any places of holding. 
Continue to scan your body, moving down the arms and hands and into your fingers.
Sense the back of your body and your lower back. 
Feeling the contact of your body with the chair if you are seated. 
Now, sensing your upper legs, your lower legs, and the feet. 
Take a full, deep breath in and a long breath out. Finish this pause by opening your eyes. 

Thank you for taking a moment to pause with us. It's time for today's lesson.

rows.transcript:
Today's pause is called a body scan. Begin by closing your eyes or maintaining a soft gaze. 
Take a full breath in and a long breath out.
Now, bringing awareness to the top of your body,
your head,
face,
neck,
shoulders.
Noticing any sensations, movements, any places of holding. 
Continue to scan your body, moving down the arms and hands and into your fingers.
Sense the back of your body and your lower back. 
Feeling the contact of your body with the chair if you are seated. 
Now, sensing your upper legs, your lower legs, and the feet. 
Take a full, deep breath in and a long breath out. Finish this pause by opening your eyes. 

Thank you for taking a moment to pause with us. It's time for today's lesson.

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: Wonderful, I am so happy things are going well.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: Some days will have their challenges. That is okay. You are on the right path!

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: Sorry to hear that things are difficult now. It is completely normal to struggle sometimes. Remember that you are not alone!

quiz_1_feedback_4.eng: Parenting can be stressful sometimes. Try to find a few minutes to do something relaxing.

quiz_1_feedback_5.eng: It’s normal to feel tired when you have so many responsibilities. Getting enough sleep tonight may help restore your energy for tomorrow.

rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: Wonderful, I am so happy things are going well.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: Some days will have their challenges. That is okay. You are on the right path!
rows.quiz_1_feedback_3: Sorry to hear that things are difficult now. It is completely normal to struggle sometimes. Remember that you are not alone!
rows.quiz_1_feedback_4: Parenting can be stressful sometimes. Try to find a few minutes to do something relaxing.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_5: It’s normal to feel tired when you have so many responsibilities. Getting enough sleep tonight may help restore your energy for tomorrow.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Today we will learn how to manage your child’s challenging behaviours. 
Sometimes our children act out, not because they need attention. Children need attention from a very young age. If they don’t get attention freely, they work hard to get it. These behaviours can take the form of whining, demanding, showing off, tantrums, and lots of other difficult behaviours. 

So what can we do?

rows.text_1_facilitator:
Today we will learn how to manage your child’s challenging behaviours. 
Sometimes our children act out, not because they need attention. Children need attention from a very young age. If they don’t get attention freely, they work hard to get it. These behaviours can take the form of whining, demanding, showing off, tantrums, and lots of other difficult behaviours. 

So what can we do?

text_1_facilitator.eng:
One effective strategy is learning how to manage these difficult behaviours in the right way. 

We can do this by choosing not to give attention to the behaviours we don’t want to see. 

When we stop reacting to things like whining or tantrums, our children learn that these actions won’t get them the attention they’re seeking.

Instead, we can focus on giving our children plenty of positive attention when they behave well.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
One effective strategy is learning how to manage these difficult behaviours in the right way. 

We can do this by choosing not to give attention to the behaviours we don’t want to see. 

When we stop reacting to things like whining or tantrums, our children learn that these actions won’t get them the attention they’re seeking.

Instead, we can focus on giving our children plenty of positive attention when they behave well.

text_1_facilitator.eng: @data.characters.f2_daughter_3 and her family are having lunch together :

character_2_text.eng: The household rule is one glass of juice at dinner. Come and help me bring the dessert to the table.

rows.text_1_facilitator: @data.characters.f2_daughter_3 and her family are having lunch together :
rows.character_2_text: The household rule is one glass of juice at dinner. Come and help me bring the dessert to the table.

character_1_text.eng: But I WANT some! Give me!

character_2_text.eng: @data.characters.f2_son_8.name, you are eating your dinner so nicely.

rows.character_1_text: But I WANT some! Give me!
rows.character_2_text: @data.characters.f2_son_8.name, you are eating your dinner so nicely.

character_2_text.eng: Here we go... just take a deep breath.

character_3_text.eng: @data.characters.f2_son_8.name, please fetch the cookies from the counter

rows.character_2_text: Here we go... just take a deep breath.
rows.character_3_text: @data.characters.f2_son_8.name, please fetch the cookies from the counter

character_1_text.eng: @data.characters.f2_son_8, it is so nice to see you helping out in the house.

rows.character_1_text: @data.characters.f2_son_8, it is so nice to see you helping out in the house.

character_1_text.eng: It is nice to see you sitting quietly, @data.characters.f2_daughter_3. Here, have some delicious cookies with us.

rows.character_1_text: It is nice to see you sitting quietly, @data.characters.f2_daughter_3. Here, have some delicious cookies with us.

text_1_facilitator.eng: @data.characters.f2_daughter_3’s grandparents managed her difficult behaviour. Let’s explore how they did this.

quiz_1_question.eng: What did the grandparents do when @data.characters.f2_daughter_3 demanded more juice?

quiz_1_option_1_text.eng: The grandparents ignored @data.characters.f2_daughter_3’s whining and focused on giving positive attention to @data.characters.f2_son_8

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: Correct! The grandparents removed their attention from @data.characters.f2_daughter_3’s demanding behaviour and instead praised @data.characters.f2_son_8 for his positive actions.

quiz_1_option_2_text.eng: The grandparents scolded @data.characters.f2_daughter_3 and told her to stop whining.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng:
Incorrect. Scolding @data.characters.f2_daughter_3 would have given her negative attention, reinforcing her behaviour and making the situation worse. 

Instead the grandparents removed their attention from @data.characters.f2_daughter_3’s demanding behaviour and gave positive attention to @data.characters.f2_son_8 instead.

quiz_1_option_3_text.eng: The grandparents immediately gave @data.characters.f2_daughter_3 more juice to stop her whining.

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng:
Incorrect. Giving @data.characters.f2_daughter_3 more juice would have rewarded her demanding behaviour, teaching her that whining gets results. 

Instead, the grandparents ignored her demanding behaviour and praised @data.characters.f2_son_8’s positive behaviour.

quiz_1_option_4_text.eng: The grandparents left the room to avoid hearing @data.characters.f2_daughter_3’s whining.

quiz_1_feedback_4.eng: Incorrect. Leaving the room could have made @data.characters.f2_daughter_3 feel neglected and unsafe. The grandparents stayed present but chose to ignore the whining behaviour while praising @data.characters.f2_son_8.

quiz_2_question.eng: How do the grandparents ignore @data.characters.f2_daughter_3’s behaviour?

quiz_2_option_1_text.eng: They look directly at @data.characters.f2_daughter_3 but stayed silent.

quiz_2_feedback_1.eng:
Incorrect. Looking directly at @data.characters.f2_daughter_3 would still give her some attention, which could reinforce her behaviour. 

The grandparents turned their body away from @data.characters.f2_daughter_3, avoided eye contact, and did not speak to her. 

The grandparents were aware of @data.characters.f2_daughter_3 at all times.

quiz_2_option_2_text.eng: They turn their body away from @data.characters.f2_daughter_3, avoid eye contact, and do not speak to her.

quiz_2_feedback_2.eng:
Correct! By turning their body away, avoiding eye contact, and not speaking, the grandparents effectively remove all attention from @data.characters.f2_daughter_3’s demanding behaviour.


The grandparents were aware of @data.characters.f2_daughter_3 at all times.

quiz_2_option_3_text.eng: @data.characters.f2_grandfather quietly asks @data.characters.f2_daughter_3 to stop whining but does not yell at her

quiz_2_feedback_3.eng:
Incorrect. Even quietly asking @data.characters.f2_daughter_3 to stop whining gives her verbal attention, which could reinforce her behaviour. 

The grandparents turn their body away from @data.characters.f2_daughter_3, avoid eye contact, and do not speak to her. 
The grandparents were aware of @data.characters.f2_daughter_3 at all times.

quiz_2_option_4_text.eng: They leave the room to ignore her completely.

quiz_2_feedback_4.eng:
Incorrect. Leaving the room might not be safe. Remember, you want to not give attention to the negative behaviour, not ignore the child. 

The grandparents stay present but turn their body away from @data.characters.f2_daughter_3, avoid eye contact, and do not speak to her.

quiz_3_question.eng: Why do you think it is important that the family members continue to not give attention to @data.characters.f2_daughter_3’s difficult behaviour?

quiz_3_option_1_text.eng: Because it will make her feel unloved and teach her a lesson

quiz_3_feedback_1.eng:
Incorrect. The purpose is not to make the child feel unloved or to “teach a lesson”. 

When you don’t give attention to negative behaviour, you  avoid reinforcing negative behaviour. You still show love and attention when the child behaves positively. 

It’s important that children feel secure and cared for, even when we are not giving attention to specific challenging behaviours.

quiz_3_option_2_text.eng: Because if they give her attention, she will learn that she gets attention only when she increases her demands.

quiz_3_feedback_2.eng: Correct! Giving attention to @data.characters.f2_daughter_3’s behaviour would reinforce it, teaching her that escalating demands is a successful strategy for getting what she wants.

quiz_3_option_3_text.eng: Because not giving attention to her behaviour will make her stop immediately and never act out again.

quiz_3_feedback_3.eng:
Incorrect. Not giving attention to negative behaviour may not stop the behaviour immediately. 

Sometimes when parents begin to ignore a specific difficult behaviour, that behaviour might get worse for a while. 

After a short while, however, the behaviour will start to decrease, especially if parents are giving their children other positive ways of getting attention. 

The key is consistency, so the child learns over time that demands and tantrums will not be rewarded

Incorrect. Scolding @data.characters.f2_daughter_3 would have given her negative attention, reinforcing her behaviour and making the situation worse.

Instead, the grandparents ignored her demanding behaviour and praised @data.characters.f2_son_8’s positive behaviour.

The key is consistency, so the child learns over time that demands and tantrums will not be rewarded

quiz_1_question.eng: What does the @data.characters.f2_grandfather do when @data.characters.f2_daughter_3’s tantrum is over?

quiz_1_option_1_text.eng: He praises her for sitting quietly

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng:
Correct! Praising @data.characters.f2_daughter_3 for her calm behaviour helps reinforce positive behaviour. He also invites her to have dessert together. 

Both the praise and involving her in another activity provide @data.characters.f2_daughter_3 some comfort after a difficult experience.

quiz_1_option_2_text.eng: He tells her that she needs to apologise for the tantrum before having dessert.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng:
Incorrect. Focusing on the tantrum would only remind @data.characters.f2_daughter_3 of the negative behaviour. She could start the tantrum again.  

The grandfather instead praises her for her calm behaviour and invites her to have dessert together.

quiz_1_option_3_text.eng: He ignores her completely and continues to pay attention only to @data.characters.f2_son_8

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng:
Incorrect. Once the tantrum is over, it is important to give @data.characters.f2_daughter_3 positive attention for calm behaviour. 

Ignoring her at this point would miss an opportunity to reinforce the behaviour you want to see.

rows.quiz_1_feedback_1:
Correct! Praising @data.characters.f2_daughter_3 for her calm behaviour helps reinforce positive behaviour. He also invites her to have dessert together. 

Both the praise and involving her in another activity provide @data.characters.f2_daughter_3 some comfort after a difficult experience.

The grandfather instead praises her for her calm behaviour and invites her to have dessert together.

Ignoring her at this point would miss an opportunity to reinforce the behaviour you want to see.

text_1_facilitator.eng: Here are some tips on ignoring challenging behaviour:

text_2.eng:
**Pay attention** 
- Notice when your child wants or needs positive attention.
- Listen to what your child says and give attention to his/her positive behaviour.
- If you are doing something important, take a moment to acknowledge your child and redirect her/him to something that will occupy her/his attention.
- Pay more attention to the behaviour you want more of, and less attention to the behaviour you want less of.

**Redirect First** 
- Try to redirect or distract your child before ignoring.
- Redirect works best for younger children.
- Use a calm voice and a new activity: “Let’s play ball together instead.”
- Encourage the opposite of the problem behaviour with rewards and praise.

**How to Ignore** 
- Arguing, sulking, screaming, interrupting, whining, teasing, and sometimes even swearing are behaviours that may be ignored. 
- Ignoring behaviour is sometimes the best response to difficult behaviour.
- Ignore means no eye contact, no physical contact, and no verbal contact.
- Ignore only the behaviour, not the child.
- Behaviours that may be ignored include: arguing, sulking, whining, teasing, interrupting, screaming, or mild swearing.
- Do not ignore aggressive or dangerous behaviours that risk safety.
- Ignoring is a group effort. Everyone in the family must join in.
- Ignore works better for children ages 4 and older; Redirect younger children
- As soon as the negative behaviour ends, praise the next positive behaviour immediately.

**Be Prepared** 
- Ignoring can make behaviour get worse at first before it gets better. Be patient!
- Stay calm—use your own calming strategies (deep breaths, pausing, walking away).
- Be consistent when choosing to ignore difficult behavior.
- Ignoring is easier if we have decided how we are going to act when ignoring.

- Redirect works best for younger children.

- Encourage the opposite of the problem behaviour with rewards and praise.

**How to Ignore**

- Ignoring behaviour is sometimes the best response to difficult behaviour.
- Ignore means no eye contact, no physical contact, and no verbal contact.

- Be consistent when choosing to ignore difficult behavior.
- Ignoring is easier if we have decided how we are going to act when ignoring.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Your home activity is to practise ignoring one challenging behaviour. 

First try once to Redirect your child’s attention to a positive behaviour.

Only work with one challenging behaviour this week. You can do what you normally do with the other behaviours for now. Otherwise, it will be too much at once for your child
